org.opentcs.access.rmi

Class KernelProxyBuilder

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.opentcs.access.rmi.KernelProxyBuilder

  • public class KernelProxyBuilder
extends java.lang.Object
    Builds KernelProxy instances for connections to remote kernels.

    If the kernel you want to connect to is running on a host named "foobar", you usually only have to do the following: 

     Kernel kernel = new KernelProxyBuilder().setHost("foobar").build();

    You can then use kernel to call methods on the proxy, which will be wrapped by RMI calls internally and forwarded to the remote kernel you connected to. This interface to the kernel can e.g. be used to create transport orders from clients - see the developer's guide for code examples.

    After being built, the proxy will immediately start polling periodically for events with the remote kernel. You can use a custom intervals and timeouts for polling by setting the respective build parameters. To receive these events in your client code, register an event listener with the proxy by calling its EventSource.addEventListener(org.opentcs.util.eventsystem.EventListener) method. The proxy will then forward events to your registered listener.

      • build

        public KernelProxy build()
                  throws KernelUnavailableException,
                         CredentialsException
        Builds and returns a KernelProxy with the configured parameters.
        Returns:
        A proxy for the remote kernel.
        Throws:
        KernelUnavailableException - If the remote kernel is not reachable for some reason.
        CredentialsException - If the client login with the remote kernel failed, e.g. because of incorrect login data.
        See Also:
        RemoteKernel.pollEvents(ClientID, long)
